I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Midterm Review (MTR) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s Strategy 2020 
emphasizes the importance of enhancing the provision of knowledge solutions to developing 
member countries (DMCs), and stresses that the value provided by ADB operations includes 
delivering up-to-date knowledge products and services (KPS) and cross-country experiences, in 
addition  to  finance.  Knowledge  and  knowledge  management  are  recognized  as  important 
elements of ADB’s finance++ approach, integrating ADB financing with support for knowledge 
solutions. 1  
2.  This technical assistance (TA) project has been developed to strengthen ADB’s delivery 
of KPS to DMCs. In particular, it will assist DMCs covered by ADB’s Central and West Asia 
Department (CWRD) adopt better knowledge solutions and catalyze transformative innovation 
in these countries.2 It will also conduct a study aimed at strengthening the impact of ADB’s 
development  operations  in  Central  and West Asian  countries,  by  increasing  promotion for 
inclusive growth through ADB projects.3 
3.  The TA conceptualization has benefited from consultations with governments and other 
local stakeholders in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, 
Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. Discussions were held in particular with the ministries 
of economy, energy, finance, and transport, as well as local think tanks and research institutes. 
The  TA  design  benefited  as  well  from  substantial  input  received  from  resident  missions, 
divisions, and units through regular meetings with knowledge focal points and their supervisors. 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Central and West Asian countries (footnote 2) currently face several challenges related 
to  weakening  energy  prices,  devaluation  of  their  currencies,  increasing  inflation,  and  an 
economic  slowdown  in  the  countries  that  are  their  major  trading  partners  and  sources  of 
remittances. Economic vulnerabilities are often related to poor economic diversification, low 
labor productivity, low levels of domestic savings, and insufficient development of the private 
sector. Increasingly, problems with income distribution hamper the achievement of inclusive 
growth, while various unresolved issues—including with gender equality, access to finance and 
education, and a mismatch between labor demand and skills formation—create obstacles to 
inclusive development. Most Central and West Asian economies are in the middle-income 
group, and are at risk of falling into the middle-income trap, preventing them from shifting to 
higher-income levels. Expanding their ability to generate, manage, and share knowledge is 
essential to overcoming these challenges and mitigating the structural risks inherent in their 
economies.  
5.  Furthermore, the importance of introducing focused, well-structured knowledge solutions 
increases for upper middle-income countries; in order to enhance people’s quality of life and 
enable cutting-edge technological development, these countries need to considerably expand 
their capacity to innovate. Knowledge is also needed to promote economic development in 
lower-income  countries,  those that  suffer from  structural  vulnerabilities,  and those  in  post-
conflict situations. These countries can use knowledge solutions to distill lessons from countries

that  have  experienced  similar  challenges,  and  can  enable  economic  growth  by  adopting 
international best practices. 
6.  As DMCs in Central and West Asia implement policies and develop institutions that 
facilitate the structural transformation of their economies, the expansion of knowledge and 
learning from successful experiences are increasingly important. To enhance the quality and 
effective dissemination of KPS, the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 (footnote 1) calls for 
knowledge  partnerships  and  dialogue  opportunities  with  local  think  tanks  and  research 
institutes. 
7.  A common theme that emerged from consultations with governments is the generalized 
perception that inequality has recently increased across the region. Despite the progress made 
by Central Asian economies in recent years, the ongoing economic difficulties resulting from the 
decline  in  energy  prices  and  devaluation  of  regional  currencies  is  significantly  disrupting 
economic activity, with resulting negative impacts on jobs, remittances, and people’s general 
well-being.4  Local  experts  suggested  that  the  most  vulnerable  groups—including  women, 
persons with disabilities, those living in rural areas, the less literate, and migrant workers—are 
most heavily impacted. These emerging concerns will require a dedicated study focused on 
issues related to creating jobs to promote inclusive growth in the region, including analyses to 
better understand the demand and supply sides of the labor market, access to economic 
opportunities, the actual extent and distribution of poverty, and wealth and income disparities—
and ultimately to guide ADB operations. 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA impact will be aligned with the long-term economic development strategies of 
Central and West Asian countries by promoting their ability to use KPS. The TA outcome will be 
enhanced KPS delivery to DMCs. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will generate the following outputs: (i) enhanced delivery of demand-based KPS; 
(ii) compilation of data on KPS in Central and West Asia in support of the ADB-wide k-Nexus 
database;5 and (iii) completion of a study on jobs to promote inclusive growth in Central and 
West Asia, aimed at enhancing ADB operations. In particular, DMC demand for KPS has been 
discussed with governments and local stakeholders during missions organized in 2015, and it 
has been considered in the preparation of country knowledge plans (CKPs).  
10.  The creation of a KPS database is intended to help effectively manage KPS demands 
from DMCs and will be consistent with ADB’s k-Nexus initiative. It will include an inventory of 
KPS delivered from January 2006 through June 2017. KPS reports will also be published and 
guidelines for maintaining and uploading the database will be prepared. The region-wide study 
is expected to be divided into three parts: (i) an analytical framework for inclusive growth, 
tailored to capture the existing economic environment in Central and West Asia; (ii) issues and 
policies  related  to  job  creation,  skill  formation,  and  labor  migration;  and  (iii)  promotion  of 
economic inclusiveness through improved ADB project design and operations in Central and 
                                                
4  ADB. 2015. Asian Development Outlook: Financing Asia’s Future Growth. Manila.  
5  The ADB-wide k-Nexus initiative is an output under the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020; it is an online database 
that lists completed, ongoing and planned ADB KPS.

West Asia. In addition to a final report delivered as a flagship publication, the study will generate 
several other knowledge products (e.g., technical notes, policy briefs, blogs, opinion essays, 
and other documents to help inform country partnership strategies and CKPs). Considerable 
effort will be made to disseminate the study through the region and beyond. 
11.  The TA assumes the presence of the following risks: (i) absorptive capacity of DMCs 
remains weak, (ii) DMC bureaucratic processes hinder effective use of knowledge, (iii) internal 
government processes may delay the identification of the demand for specific KPS, (iv) a lack of 
complete and accurate information on KPS delivered in previous years, and (v) a lack of interest 
by DMCs to accept and endorse the study and its recommendations. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency, with CWRD’s Regional Cooperation and Operations 
Coordination Division (CWRC) as the focal point. Activities organized under the TA will include 
organization of and participation in knowledge events such as workshops, conferences, and 
seminars.6 The TA will be implemented over a period of 29 months, from August 2015 to 
December 2017. The TA will require approximately 145 person-months of inputs from the 
following consulting services: 
(i)  To assist with KPS delivery to DMCs, international and national consultants, as 
well as think tanks/research institutes from Central and West Asia DMCs will be 
engaged on specific assignments, in close coordination with resident missions. 
The pool of consultants will include international consultants (total of about 15 
person-months of services) and national consultants (total of about 52 person-
months of services), including for editorial and translation work. 
(ii)  To assist with knowledge management coordination, national consultants will be 
engaged in ADB headquarters for about 29 person-months; assignments will 
include support in preparing guidelines for the KPS database, its maintenance, 
and  update;  conducting  the  KPS  stocktaking  exercise;  and  facilitating  the 
publication of KPS reports.  
(iii)  To assist with drafting and finalizing specialized topics related to the study, the 
TA will engage several international consultants, including an economics editor. 
Local think tanks/research institutes and peer reviewers will be engaged to help 
with  preparing  background  papers,  conducting  surveys  and  interviews  as 
needed, gathering and analyzing data, and performing quality control. The TA will 
engage  national  consultants  to  assist  with  data  gathering  and  analysis, 
coordination, communication, and organization of knowledge events.7 
                                                
6  ADB staff involved with the TA may participate as resource persons in knowledge-sharing events, which will collect 
feedback and suggestions on improving the activities being implemented under the TA.

14.  To provide the above services under (i) the TA will engage individual consultants and 
think  tanks/research  institutes  on  a  case-by-case  basis,  based  on  DMC  KPS  needs. 
Requirements will be formulated through specific KPS templates, including details about the 
terms of references for consulting services. Requests will be evaluated on the basis of their 
expected contribution to filling knowledge gaps identified in DMC CKPs. Rankings will be made 
by CWRC based on funding availability and the comparative urgency of proposals. Eligible KPS 
include those relating to new projects and those meant to increase the knowledge component of 
ongoing projects, or bridge with pipeline projects. 
15.  Consulting services (para. 13) will be sourced from individual consultants and/or think 
tanks/research institutes. Individual consultants will be engaged pursuant to ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). In some cases, consulting 
services may be rendered through output-based contracts and lump-sum payments. Due to the 
specific nature of the services involved and the low contractual amounts, about 8–10 think 
tanks/research institutes will be engaged as consulting firms through single-source selection 
using  biodata  technical  proposals,  in  close  consultation  with  DMC  governments  and  ADB 
resident missions. Think tanks/research institutes will be identified from August 2015 to March 
2016  and  listed  in  a  separate  memorandum  to  ADB’s  Operations  Services  and  Financial 
Management Department upon completion of consultation missions.  
16.  Resource  persons  will  also  be  engaged,  based  on  their  academic  and/or  policy 
backgrounds and qualifications, to serve as peer reviewers for knowledge products, and present 
papers and/or act as facilitators, speakers, and panelists in knowledge-sharing events such as 
conferences, workshops, seminars, and capacity building programs. 
17.  Disbursements under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  cost  estimates  for 
engaging consultants and their indicative positions are in the cost estimates and financing plan 
(Appendix 2) and outline terms of reference for consultants (Appendix 3). All procurement will 
be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time 
to time). Upon completion of the TA, all procured equipment will be transferred to ADB. 
18.  CWRC will monitor TA progress and suggest actions to ensure the effective delivery of 
TA outputs. The TA will be monitored through KPS reports, and biannual progress reports 
prepared  by  the  knowledge  management  coordinator  that  detail  the  TA  work  program, 
methodology, and timelines for finalizing the KPS stocktaking exercise and database creation, 
as well as the planning and delivery of KPS based on DMC requests. In addition, the region-
wide study coordinator will prepare inception, interim and final reports detailing the study outline, 
methodology, work program, milestone events, and outputs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Strengthening Knowledge Management in Central and West Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will include a total of about 145 person-months of services 
from international and national consultants to assist with delivery of its three key outputs: (i) 
delivery  of  demand-based  knowledge  products  and  services  (KPS); (ii)  creation  of  a  KPS 
database; and (iii) completion of a region-wide study of inclusive growth in Central and West 
Asian countries. 
 
2.  Economists, sector experts, and knowledge events facilitators (international and, 
national, think thanks/research institutes, 45 person-months, intermittent). Several international 
and national experts, each with at least 7 years of experience in their respective fields, as well 
as local think thanks and research institutes will be engaged on an intermittent basis to assist 
with the delivery of KPS based on requests formulated by developing member countries (DMCs) 
and channeled through resident missions of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The full KPS 
list and definition are in Supplementary Appendix A (available upon request). Consultant profiles 
will be detailed in the individual project proposals. Their specific assignments may include the 
following: 
(i)  contribute (in cooperation with ADB staff) to the preparation of economic, sector, 
and thematic studies; and reports, papers, manuals, guidelines, briefs, notes, 
articles; and blogs; 
(ii)  create websites and webpages; 
(iii)  serve as resource speakers and facilitators for conferences, summits, seminars, 
workshops, conferences, policy dialogues, training programs, study tours, and 
book launches; 
(iv)  facilitate the  organization  of knowledge-sharing  events  such  as  conferences, 
summits, seminars, workshops, meetings, policy dialogues, training programs, 
study tours, media briefings, and book launches; and 
(v)  edit, translate, and assist with the printing and publication of KPS. 
 
3.  Inclusive  growth  and  labor  market  experts  (3  international,  12  person-months, 
intermittent). Three experts will be engaged to assist with the drafting of the study. The experts, 
who will possess at least a master’s (and preferably a doctoral) degree in economics or the 
social sciences, will have a proven track record of high-quality outputs and analysis on issues 
related to inclusive growth, with at least 10 years of experience in their respective fields. Under 
the guidance of the ADB task manager and in close collaboration with other ADB staff and the 
entire study team, they will contribute to the three parts of the study, respectively, on: (i) part 1: 
an analytical framework for jobs for inclusive growth in Central and West Asia, based on the 
publication Inequality in Asia and the Pacific, and including a set of specific economic indicators 
and aspects of the political economy;1 (ii) part 2: issues and policies related to job creation, skill 
formation, and labor migration; and (iii) part 3: improving the promotion of inclusive growth and 
job creation in ADB projects through improved project design and operations in Central and 
West Asia. The experts’ assignments will include the following tasks: 
(i)  draft  relevant  parts  of  the  study  in  accordance  with  ADB  quality  standards, 
ensuring the study is analytically sound; 
(ii)  revise drafts based on comments provided by the task manager and other ADB 
staff; 
(iii)  attend study milestone events as requested by the task manager; 
(iv)  provide suggestions on ways to structure the various parts of the study;

Manila: Routledge and ADB.

(v)  review  in  detail  the  substance  of  all  papers  and  chapters  related  to  their 
respective parts of the study and provide written comments to ensure the quality 
of submissions is high; 
(vi)  draft the study’s highlights and executive summary related to their respective 
parts and revise these based on comments provided by the task manager; and 
(vii)  perform any other reasonably related task as may be requested by the task 
manager. 
 
4.  Economics  editor  for  the  region-wide  study  (international,  3  person-months, 
intermittent). The editor will preferably have an advanced degree in economics, social sciences 
or communication, English literature, language, journalism, or any field that requires writing skill, 
or an equivalent combination of education and experience. The editor will be familiar with the 
literature on inclusive growth, and with the economic development trends of Central and West 
Asian countries. The editor will have at least 10 years of experience in the field; excellent writing 
and technical assessment skills; extensive experience in editing academic and policy-oriented 
papers and reports prepared by international organizations; and will edit the three parts of the 
study,  incorporating  the  review  comments  by  the  task  manager  and  other  ADB  staff. 
Specifically, the tasks the editor will perform include the following: 
(i)  discuss with the task manager and other study experts the report’s respective 
parts and identify ways to effectively deliver the intended messages—including 
suggesting  areas  for  improvement;  if  needed,  rewriting,  adding,  or  deleting 
information;  and  revising  the  order  of  statements  and  sections  of  various 
chapters  to  tighten  the  economic  arguments,  and  ensure  that  ideas  flow 
smoothly; 
(ii)  provide  timely  and  professional  economic  editing  of  the  study’s  report  final 
manuscript and ensure, in coordination with the experts assigned to each of the 
three parts of the study, that the arguments are logical and based on sound 
theory and principles; 
(iii)  review the study’s analytical framework, ensuring consistency of logic and rigor, 
including consistency with economic theory, as appropriate, as well as empirical 
evidence; check the analytical robustness, in economic terms, of each study part 
and chapter; and ensure the coherence and consistency of the final report; 
(iv)  ensure that proper tables, figures, charts, and boxes are used to support the 
content of the report and deliver its messages; 
(v)  modify academic language into writing that is suitable for a policy-oriented report, 
one that is easily understood by political leaders and lay readers; 
(vi)  ensure internal consistency in accordance with the ADB Handbook of Style and 
Usage;2 and 
(vii)  ensure that the same effective language style is used consistently throughout the 
publication. 
 
5.  Knowledge management coordinator (national, 21 person-months). The coordinator 
will be an expert in knowledge management for international organizations with a proven track 
record of excellent outputs in this field. The coordinator will have at least 7 years of experience 
in knowledge management and be a graduate in economics, social sciences, or communication 
sciences. The coordinator’s deliverables will include, but are not limited, to the following tasks: 
(i)  provide  administrative  assistance  and  establish  effective  communication  as

(ii)  conduct a detailed inventory of KPS delivered by  CWRD, headquarters and 
resident missions, for January 2006–June 2017 (TA output 2);  
(iii)  provide inputs to and assist with the publication of two KPS reports, under the 
guidance of the TA task manager; 
(iv)  prepare bi-annual overall TA progress reports;  
(v)  coordinate closely with the data management expert, under the guidance of the 
TA task manager, on using an information technology (IT) platform to conduct the 
KPS inventory and publish the KPS reports; and 
(vi)  assist on other knowledge management coordination tasks within the TA scope, 
as requested by the task manager. 
 
6.  Data management expert (national, 8 person-months, intermittent). The consultant will 
be engaged to assist in the KPS stocktaking exercise, and the creation and maintenance of the 
KPS database using an appropriate, cost-effective and user-friendly IT platform that is aligned 
with  and  supportive  of the  ADB  k-Nexus. The  consultant  will  have  a  degree  in  computer 
science,  IT,  network  administration,  or  any  computer-related field  with  at  least  5  years of 
experience in database design and management. Specifically, the consultant will assist with the 
following tasks: 
(i)  conceptualizing, setting-up and implementing a KPS database that is aligned 
with and in support of the ADB k-Nexus database, and which can be easily 
shared, managed, and maintained by ADB staff;  
(ii)  preparing guidelines for database creation and management;  
(iii)  providing training to CWRD staff on the use of the database;  
(iv)  conducting the KPS stocktaking exercise in two phases: (a) for 20122015; and 
(b) for 2006June 2017; 
(v)  working with the knowledge management coordinator to ensure that data and 
information received from CWRD sector divisions, resident missions and units 
involved in the KPS stocktaking exercise are accurately inputted in the database;  
(vi)  the knowledge management coordinator’s preparation of two KPS reports;  
(vii)  coordinating with relevant ADB departments on IT-related matters, as necessary; 
and  
(viii)  undertaking any other reasonable IT-related task assigned by the task manager.   
 
7.  Region-wide study coordinator (national, 24 person-months). The consultant will have 
at least a master’s and preferably a doctoral degree in economics, with expertise on issues 
related to inclusive growth. The coordinator will have at least 7 years of experience in the field to 
assist  the  task  manager  with  the  overall  coordination  of  the  study,  including  with  the 
organization of milestone events. The study coordinator will also draft relevant parts of the 
study, including tables, charts, and boxes; and maintain proper communication among ADB 
staff, consultants, government officials, and other individuals involved with the study. Given the 
geographical  coverage  of  the  study,  in  addition  to  strong  written  and  oral  skills  in  the 
coordinator’s native language, the consultant will also preferably possess strong skills in written 
and oral Russian. The coordinator’s tasks will include, but are not limited, to the following:  
(i)  conduct literature reviews, surveys, and data analysis; 
(ii)  draft relevant parts of the study—including tables, charts, and boxes—on the 
basis of instructions received by the task manager; monitor the progress made 
by individual contributors (authors, reviewers, and advisers) to the study, review 
in detail the substance of the study manuscript, and provide comments to ensure 
its high quality; 
(iii)  maintain proper communication with all individuals involved with the study;

(iv)  assist in organizing study-related milestone events (e.g., workshops, seminars, 
and conferences); 
(v)  prepare an inception and a final report to inform ADB Management regarding the 
study  progress,  including  details  on  the  report’s  outline,  methodology,  work 
program, milestone events, and outputs; and 
(vi)  perform any other reasonably related task as may be requested by the task 
manager. 
 
8.  Data analysts (national, intermittent, 10 person-months). One or two local consultants 
will be hired on an intermittent basis to assist with data gathering and analysis. The analyst(s) 
will possess a master’s and preferably a doctoral degree in economics, statistics, econometrics, 
mathematics, or a related subject. The data analyst(s) will have at least 5 years of experience in 
the field, and assist in performing the tasks listed below and other reasonable assignments 
provided by the task manager: 
(i)  make an inventory of existing data, statistics, and information to be used in the 
study; 
(ii)  conduct relevant data collection and analysis; 
(iii)  prepare tables, figures, charts, and other material as requested by the task 
manager; 
(iv)  draft relevant parts of the study related to data explanation and analysis; and 
(v)  attend milestone study events, as requested by the task manager. 
 
9.  Editors and translators of knowledge products and services (national, 22 person-
months, intermittent). A pool of up to five consultants will be engaged on an intermittent basis to 
assist with editing  in English and Russian, and translation of KPS into Russian, as requested by 
DMCs. The editors and translators will have at least 5 years of experience and possess degrees 
in economics, social sciences, communication, literature, journalism, or a field requiring writing 
skill. They will be familiar with Central and West Asian countries and the literature on inclusive 
growth. The editors and translators will ensure the high quality of KPS language and style, and 
consistency of writing, in English and Russian as needed. They will also ensure the high quality 
of TA-related publications (e.g., journals, paper series, and magazines). The consultants’ key 
assignments will include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(i)  edit papers and reports for internal consistency in accordance with the ADB 
Handbook of Style and Usage; 
(ii)  translate text, proficiently and effectively, from English into Russian and from 
Russian into English, as requested by the task manager; 
(iii)  ensure that language style is consistent throughout the publication; 
(iv)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, bibliographies, and parts of the 
text; 
(v)  edit notes to make sure that text references are correct; 
(vi)  be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the text, tables, and charts in the 
paper(s) and report(s), and take the work from preliminary draft to final copy; and 
(vii)  perform any other reasonably related task as may be requested by the task 
manager. 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
